title.narrative: Skills and business conditions development of re- starting South-Sudanese private IDP entrepreneurs

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: Narrative report

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value:
As this training was a Refresher Course mostly for OKP/NFP alumni from courses organized by Ecopolis, the capacity needs assessment for the training was based on Ecopolis' previous experience with the trainees. The training deepened the alumni's understanding of the important role that businesspeople fulfill in their communities, and the challenges they are facing in providing the crucial economic services in the remote IDP settlements. These challenges are partly a result of the way that donors, (I)NGOs and TVET providers perceive and act towards private IDP entrepreneurs. The alumni and Ecopolis conducted a critical analysis of current IDP Relief and Reconstruction programmes, in which many ineffective projects were found due to limited pre-study, follow-up and needs assessments. The next step was to respond to these findings by developing and testing, in collaboration with two groups of private IDP entrepreneurs, strategies and methods to improve their professional skills and business conditions. Together with the target group, a sustainable support system was set up through a structural mentoring programme, the constitution of VSLAs, and opening the possibility of access to loans by opening a bank account for the VSLA and even the realistic possibility of Agent Banking for the town-based banks like Stanbic.
Both Ecopolis and its alumni consider the training to have been effective in reaching its objectives. The alumni and Ecopolis re-established and strengthened their relationship and willingness to assist each other. The alumni also built a strong relationship with the two pilot groups of IDP entrepreneurs in the settlements, which can form the basis for sustainable future collaboration and expansion of support to IDP entrepreneurs in other zones. The strategies and methods set up during the training practically support the crucially important move from Relief to Reconstruction, and from dependence to self-reliance. The solutions developed during the training, for instance the mentoring programme and the self-governing VSLAs with access to loans, take into account the mobile character of the target group, and have the potential to remain well-functioning support systems even when international IDP support moves on to different locations.
The closing public workshop of this refresher course, allowed the alumni , as well as representatives of the IDP entrepreneur target group to exchange and discuss with relevant stakeholders in IDP development, like local and national government, (international) NGOs, business training providers and IDP organizations. Furthermore, after the refresher course's closure, Ecopolis will -together with the alumni- continue to provide supports especially coaching of the trained local mentors for IDP entrepreneurs. Also, from early 2022, every 3 months the alumni and organizations participating in the last public workshop will organize 'Briefing Discussions" on ongoing IDP business development initiatives, activities, outcomes.
​
**Lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period**
- It's important to realise that -in terms of meaningful target group organization-just 'setting up a VSLA and opening a bank account' is not a silver bullet solution that works the same in every context. It should be acknowledged (and embraced) that each group is unique, and therefore requires its unique approach. Therefore, a programme like this should not immediately be rolled out and focus on quantitative indicators to measure project success. It's better to keep it small, and set up truly sustainable groups that will provide economic services for both the IDP and host community in the future, than to set up 20 VSLAs of which none would remain after the project support ends. - Extra attention should be given to upcoming IDP based NGOs/CBOs. South Sudanese IDP (youth) groups have in recent years transformed from target group to co-implementers of reconciliation, to grass-roots subcontractors in IDP target group facilitation and support, and -indeed- to competitors of the Juba and Kampala-based regular professional implementers of IDP livelihood and reconstruction activities. Other than that these groups have more affinity with the 'target group' and understand their challenges and opportunities better, they are also more likely to continue supporting them in the future, when interest of international organisation may move on to other locations. - When setting up a continuous mentoring programme with mentors from within the community, it is important that there is someone that these mentors can approach when they run into challenges. In short, the mentors should also have access to advisors providing continuous mentor coaching. They could also serve as the bridge between these advisors and the VSLA they are part of, when the VSLA or constituent members run into problems or have identified relevant training needs. - In developing support, training and coaching for IDP target groups, it should be born in mind that these are in principle mobile groups. They eventually move back to their home villages, or, (as would be probably be the case with the majority of South Sudanese refugees in Northern Uganda), to other places in Uganda that provide better conditions for developing their livelihoods. If they do so, "checking out as an IDP" in UNHCR terms , it does not mean that they do not need any support anymore. Providers of IDP training and business support should therefore find ways of connecting to groups and individuals in stead of locations. This refresher course has taken up that issue and developed some remedial approaches. Future periodical monitoring and periodical discussion of the results with relevant stakeholders -as agreed in the final public workshop of the refresher course- should facilitate the absorption of the new IDP support methods into the policies and programs of the mainstream international IDP support organizations.
​

actual.value: Gender awareness has improved among the alumni, helped by the fact that 8 of the 12 participants were female. This gave interesting dynamics during the RC, also in the interactions with the IDP entrepreneur groups. The participants of the RC have increased their knowledge on gender-related challenges and opportunities for businesspeople, and the need for this awareness in organising fitting trainings and meetings when engaging with the target group.

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value:
Personal attitudes have changed both in the group of alumni, as well as in the IDP entrepreneurs they worked with. Among the alumni, the increased collaboration with the IDP entrepreneurs has deepened and therefore nuanced their understanding of the group, and their role as the 'economic fabric' of their communities. It has also made them more aware of the limited support this group has so far received, and the importance of supporting them in fulfilling their important economic and social functions inside the settlements.
Among the IDP entrepreneurs themselves, a slow but important change in attitude is also observed, although at different speeds in both IDP groups. Many of the entrepreneurs show a gradual move from a 'dependent and receiving' attitude towards support, to a more 'self-reliance' oriented attitude.
